Award.AwardTitle: Biomolecular Characterization via Radical Directed Dissociation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Ryan R. Julian of the University of California Riverside is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) Program in the Directorate for Biological Sciences to further develop his mass spectrometry methodologies, which were initially developed for the identification and characterization of peptides and proteins. The project will expand the scope of biomolecules to which mass spectrometry can be applied, opening up new avenues of scientific research in numerous fields including molecular biology, biochemistry and medicine. Specifically, the proposed methods for improved oligosaccharide analysis are destined to be broadly useful as these are biologically and biomedically important molecules for which existing tools are only moderately useful. In this context, the project promises to enhance our understanding of life processes. In the course of conducting this research, graduate and undergraduate students will acquire valuable skills in bioanalytical technologies, mass spectrometry and chemical synthesis. The PI will actively participate in UCR programs (GradEDge and AGEP) that are focused on the successful advancement of minority students within the graduate school, and the research team will participate in science fairs and science demonstrations at local K-12 schools

The project is organized in three specific objectives: (1) to explore the utility of radical directed dissociation (RDD) for the elucidation of the structure of oligosaccharides and to delineate the unique fragmentation pathways that RDD produce in oligosaccharides. The focus of this objective will be on a range of targets including glycosaminoglycans, O- and N- linked glycans and glycopeptides; (2) to use RDD to identify antioxidant peptides and determine their solution phase antioxidant capacity. The inherent antioxidant capacity of biologically relevant proteins and the factors that influence antioxidant capacity will be investigated, and a combination of sequence substitution and MS/MS experiments will be used to reveal information about how radicals are sequestered; and (3) to utilize photocaged covalent labels and photochemistry to map the higher order solution phase structure of proteins, in particular multiprotein complexes.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

Performance_Institution.Name: The Regents of the University of California

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has led to the discovery of new methods for characterizing biological molecules such as proteins and lipids. These molecules are important for understanding how our bodies function. Therefore, it is important to determine the structures of these molecules, including the precise arrangement of atoms comprising them. Lipids are small molecules that help form cells and are used for communicating signals within the body. The tails of lipids are important but difficult to examine. We have discovered several new methods for figuring out lipid structure, including the tails. Proteins carry out most actions within the body. They are composed of long, string-like molecules that must fold up in a specific way to function. We have developed a quick and simple method for obtaining information about how proteins fold into a particular three dimensional structure. An important factor that determines the structure of a protein is the solvent that surrounds it. In biology, this solvent is always water, however it is often necessary to examine proteins in the absence of water. We explored the effect of alternate solvent systems on the structure of proteins to determine how protein structure would respond. One of the specific functions of proteins is to protect cells from damaging and reactive chemical species. Free radicals are a common and dangerous reactive species that can be effectively quenched by antioxidants. We developed a method to determine whether all proteins behave as antioxidants. Interestingly, every protein examined exhibited some degree of antioxidant capacity, suggesting that all proteins can protect more sensitive cellular components in a sacrificial fashion.


Last Modified: 11/22/2017
Modified by: Ryan R Julian
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This award has led to the discovery of new methods for characterizing biological molecules such as proteins and lipids. These molecules are important for understanding how our bodies function. Therefore, it is important to determine the structures of these molecules, including the precise arrangement of atoms comprising them. Lipids are small molecules that help form cells and are used for communicating signals within the body. The tails of lipids are important but difficult to examine. We have discovered several new methods for figuring out lipid structure, including the tails. Proteins carry out most actions within the body. They are composed of long, string-like molecules that must fold up in a specific way to function. We have developed a quick and simple method for obtaining information about how proteins fold into a particular three dimensional structure. An important factor that determines the structure of a protein is the solvent that surrounds it. In biology, this solvent is always water, however it is often necessary to examine proteins in the absence of water. We explored the effect of alternate solvent systems on the structure of proteins to determine how protein structure would respond. One of the specific functions of proteins is to protect cells from damaging and reactive chemical species. Free radicals are a common and dangerous reactive species that can be effectively quenched by antioxidants. We developed a method to determine whether all proteins behave as antioxidants. Interestingly, every protein examined exhibited some degree of antioxidant capacity, suggesting that all proteins can protect more sensitive cellular components in a sacrificial fashion.
